# NPDES Permit Application Guide (2026)

## What is an NPDES Permit?

National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System permits authorize point source discharges to waters of the United States. Required under [Clean Water Act Section 402](https://www.epa.gov/npdes).

## When NPDES is Required

- Discharge to surface waters (rivers, lakes, ocean)
- Discharge to storm drains that lead to surface waters
- Municipal wastewater treatment plants
- Industrial process water
- Cooling water
- Stormwater (certain categories)

## Types of NPDES Permits

### Individual Permits
- Site-specific conditions
- For unique discharges
- Higher scrutiny, longer process

### General Permits
- Cover categories of dischargers
- Enrollment through Notice of Intent (NOI)
- Faster process
- Examples: CGP, IGP, MS4

## Application Process (Individual Permit)

### Step 1: Pre-Application
- Contact your [Regional Water Board](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterboards_map.html)
- Discuss discharge characteristics
- Determine permit type needed

### Step 2: Gather Information

**Discharge Information:**
- Flow rates (average, maximum)
- Discharge location (coordinates)
- Receiving water name
- Existing or new discharge

**Pollutant Data:**
- Characterization sampling results
- Expected pollutant concentrations
- Treatment methods used

**Facility Information:**
- Process description
- Site map
- Treatment system design

### Step 3: Submit Application

**EPA Form 1** - General information
**EPA Form 2A, 2C, 2D, 2E, or 2F** - Depends on discharge type:
- 2A: New sources/new dischargers
- 2C: Existing manufacturing
- 2D: POTW
- 2E: Manufacturing requiring ELG
- 2F: Stormwater

### Step 4: Application Review
- Completeness check
- Technical review
- Draft permit development
- Public notice and comment

### Step 5: Permit Issuance
- Respond to comments
- Final permit issued
- 5-year term typically

## Timeline

- **Application to draft permit:** 3-12 months
- **Public notice period:** 30 days minimum
- **Final permit:** 1-3 months after close of comments
- **Total:** 6-18 months typical

## Application Fees

- Vary by discharge type and volume
- See current fee schedule
- Annual fees apply once permitted

## Key Permit Conditions

### Effluent Limitations
- Pollutant-specific discharge limits
- Based on technology and water quality

### Monitoring Requirements
- Sampling frequency
- Parameters to monitor
- Reporting requirements

### Receiving Water Monitoring
- May be required
- Upstream/downstream sampling

### Best Management Practices
- Pollution prevention
- Spill response
- Housekeeping

## CIWQS Online System

**URL:** [ciwqs.waterboards.ca.gov](https://ciwqs.waterboards.ca.gov)
**Use for:**
- Application submission (some types)
- Reporting
- Compliance tracking

## Resources

**Regional Boards:** [Waterboards Map](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterboards_map.html)
**Forms:** [EPA NPDES Forms](https://www.epa.gov/npdes/)
**State NPDES:** [SWRCB NPDES Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/npdes/)

## Take Action

1. **Determine your permit type** -- Review the [SWRCB NPDES Program](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/water_issues/programs/npdes/) page to identify whether you need an individual permit or can enroll under a general permit.
2. **Download application forms** -- Get the appropriate EPA forms (1, 2A-2F) from the [EPA NPDES page](https://www.epa.gov/npdes/) based on your discharge type.
3. **Contact your Regional Board** -- Find your board using the [Waterboards Map](https://www.waterboards.ca.gov/waterboards_map.html) and schedule a pre-application meeting to discuss discharge characteristics.
4. **Register for CIWQS** -- Set up your account at [ciwqs.waterboards.ca.gov](https://ciwqs.waterboards.ca.gov) for electronic application submission and future compliance reporting.
